content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A vehicle manufacturer is developing software for its self-driving vehicle. If the software detects that the vehicle is unintentionally deviating from its lane, the software will signal the vehicle to perform a corrective maneuver to remain in the lane. The manufacturer plans to investigate the performance of two different software programs (X and Y) across its large fleet of self-driving vehicles. A random sample of <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles was selected from the manufacturer’s fleet of self-driving vehicles and both software programs were installed in each vehicle. The vehicles were driven and the difference in software reliability scores, measured by the difference in the proportion of corrective maneuvers appropriately signaled, was recorded for each vehicle at the end of two weeks. The histogram shows the distribution of the differences in software reliability scores (X minus Y) for the <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles. (a) Describe the distribution of the differences in software reliability scores for the <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. A vehicle manufacturer is developing software for its self-driving vehicle. If the software detects that the vehicle is unintentionally deviating from its lane, the software will signal the vehicle to perform a corrective maneuver to remain in the lane. The manufacturer plans to investigate the performance of two different software programs (X and Y) across its large fleet of self-driving vehicles. A random sample of <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles was selected from the manufacturer’s fleet of self-driving vehicles and both software programs were installed in each vehicle. The vehicles were driven and the difference in software reliability scores, measured by the difference in the proportion of corrective maneuvers appropriately signaled, was recorded for each vehicle at the end of two weeks. The histogram shows the distribution of the differences in software reliability scores (X minus Y) for the <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles. (a) Describe the distribution of the differences in software reliability scores for the <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles.

The manufacturer will use a hypothesis test, at <math alttext="alpha equals 0.01" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.01</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, to determine whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that Software X has a lower software reliability score than Software Y. Let <math alttext="mu sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean difference in software reliability scores (X minus Y) for all of the manufacturer’s self-driving vehicles that could be assigned the two software programs. The hypotheses are: <math alttext="H sub 0, colon, mu sub difference equals 0. H sub a, colon, mu sub difference is less than 0." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (b) Identify a feature of the distribution of the sample differences in software reliability scores that might raise concerns about whether the sampling distribution of <math alttext="x bar sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal, and explain why it is reasonable to conclude that the sampling distribution of <math alttext="x bar sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal in this case.

Assuming all conditions for inference were met, the hypothesis test was conducted and resulted in a test statistic of <math alttext="t is approximately equal to negative 0.590" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≈</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.590</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(c) Based on the results of the hypothesis test, what conclusion can be made about the two software programs? Justify your answer.

An employee of the manufacturer believes that software reliability score is related to average distance traveled per trip, in miles. The scatterplots show, by software program, the relationship between average distance traveled per trip and software reliability score for the <math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles. (d) Describe and compare the association between average distance traveled per trip and software reliability score for the two software programs.

(e) Suppose a vehicle is randomly selected from those in the study. For which software program (X or Y) is there a smaller probability of selecting a vehicle that has a software reliability score of at least <math alttext="0.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> given an average distance traveled per trip of less than <math alttext="15" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> miles? Interpret what this means in the context of the study.

(f) Provide a recommendation to the manufacturer that describes how vehicles should be assigned to Software X or Software Y based on average distance traveled per trip if the goal is to assign the software program with the greater software reliability score. Justify your answer based on the two scatterplots.

topic.text: 1.6: Describing the Distribution of a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 2.A: Describe data presented numerically or graphically.
